1565321266_1LT3fcyEShsU9E1H5wiBceWmEpU6L.body:
A user suggested something along the lines of "we need a problem that's easy to solve for humans, hard to solve for computers, and easily verified by computers.". Though the decentralized nature of it makes it pretty difficult. 
The fact that no one has solved the issue yet tells us that zeronets small userbase has insulated it from large spam issues. I saw the admin of 08chan talk time limiting ID creation, that would do the trick for now at least.

Is the spammer a schizo? Who would have thunk. 
Can you automatically generate zeroid ID's? If not then enforcing usage of those might be an idea until we can get smarter on filtering and blocking.

> [kaffie](#comment_927_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Technically yes. Though ZeroID could ban your ip from creating new ones. But you can get around that with stuff like KaffieID (which does cert generation locally/decentralized). [...]

Interesting, but isn't KaffieID a different authority from ZeroID? I thought that an enforcement of ID's would ensure that they come from the right authority.
Pretty sad that we are forced to use centralized services, but until the decentralized tech gets some kind of user protection from spam and abuse it's gonna be a hard sell to the general public. 
POW for ID generation might be a possibility, and make any bad actors life really annoying.
For now, the best solution is limited and centralized ID providers, or a centralized captcha system.

It's not like decentralization itself is a bad idea and it's probably going to be in high demand very soon, it's just really immature and up until a few years ago it was really obscure technology. There is a lot of room for improvement for zeronet (ahem browser python turbo bloat), but that doesn't mean a robust solution can't exist. 
We're currently on the first iteration of this technology, and with how crazy internet censorship is getting there is an increasing demand for censorship resistance.

until someone solves the need for inherent trust in certificates and captcha systems, it seems we are forced to centralize the captcha under a hidden service to provide load balance and DoS protection, courtesy of the Tor guard nodes. 
Many 8chan boards use 24 hour captchas. System would work like this:
User asks hidden service for a captcha.
Hidden service sends captcha challenge.
If the response is correct, send a certificate to the client and add it to a database with a timestamp tacked on.
When the current time is certificate creation +24 hours blacklist(08chan has blacklists the admin can add ID's to) the certificate, inform the user and ask them to enter a new captcha for a new certificate.

If something like this could be decentralized it would basically solve the issues of certificate authorities and trust. Only solution would be some dedicated cryptography hardware with a unique ID built in and some private keys that enable it to certify the ID's generated, users would then ban this private key instead of a software generated ID. Spammers would need massive amounts of hardware that would get banned really quickly. You could even use the same blacklist method from before, where the blacklist is distributed with timestamps from the site owners machine, signed with his keys. Then every client could individually chose to follow the blacklist or ignore it.
